componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from Erik Bass from Autonomous Research.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: First, on Liberty National. I guess, life margins have deteriorated a bit year-to-date. This has followed a period of strong sales growth. I was just hoping you could provide some guidance on what dynamics you're seeing and what you're assuming for margin
componenttext: First, on Liberty National. I guess, life margins have deteriorated a bit year-to-date. This has followed a period of strong sales growth. I was just hoping you could provide some guidance on what dynamics you're seeing and what you're assuming for margins in your 2019 guidance.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Erik, first of all, looking at the quarter-over-quarter, the policy obligations, at 38%, it was higher for this year as compared to last year, the 36%, which was a low for 2017. So part of it's an unfavorable comparison. However, the -- we were expecting
componenttext: Erik, first of all, looking at the quarter-over-quarter, the policy obligations, at 38%, it was higher for this year as compared to last year, the 36%, which was a low for 2017. So part of it's an unfavorable comparison. However, the -- we were expecting a lower policy obligation ratio in third quarter this year because that's the normal seasonal pattern, and that pattern didn't occur. So we expect -- we do expect that that's just fluctuation and it will return back to more of a normal pattern. But still, because we had the higher order, we're going to be able to get a higher ratio this year than we were in 2017. So that's about a point difference in the margin. The other main difference in the Liberty National margins is in the non-deferred commissions and amortization expenses. We're running about a percentage point higher, running around 38% versus 37% last year. And the reason for that is because as the amortization on the business in the previous few years is higher than the amortization rate on the older in-force block of business that's running off. So -- and that will probably -- that will continue. Looking forward, for the year, we're about 24% underwriting margin. We expect to end up around that for the year. And we're also, to 2019, we're expecting the amortization percentage to creep up a little bit, but we also expect that the policy obligations will revert back to more of the 36% range as opposed to 37%. So to sum that up for 2019, we're looking for the margins to stay around that 24% level.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Erik, the one thing I would add to that is that we're seeing the non-deferred expenses creeping up just a little bit on that as well as we are expanding some of our sales there and align our sales efforts in making some investments in both the agency as w
componenttext: Erik, the one thing I would add to that is that we're seeing the non-deferred expenses creeping up just a little bit on that as well as we are expanding some of our sales there and align our sales efforts in making some investments in both the agency as well as technology investments, just supporting those future sales. But we do look on having the future sales growth from that paid back on that here over time.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Appreciate the color. And then following the debt rate and the capital contribution, you'll have the RBC ratio in the range you talked about, at the 300% to 320%. I guess, how do you think about any need to maintain a buffer in that or where you fall in t
componenttext: Appreciate the color. And then following the debt rate and the capital contribution, you'll have the RBC ratio in the range you talked about, at the 300% to 320%. I guess, how do you think about any need to maintain a buffer in that or where you fall in the range? Just for the potential impact of either a credit market downturn and ratings downgrades or if there are C1 changes from the NAIC that come through?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, we're very comfortable with our liquidity position, if you will. And so don't feel a strong need to hold a lot of buffer for some events that may or may not occur in the future. So we've been at this general level of RBC for quite some time. We k
componenttext: Yes. No, we're very comfortable with our liquidity position, if you will. And so don't feel a strong need to hold a lot of buffer for some events that may or may not occur in the future. So we've been at this general level of RBC for quite some time. We know that we have capacity within our debt-to-cap ratios and still fitting within our overall, from a rating agencies perspective, of probably about $500 million from where we kind expect to be at the end of the year. At around -- our debt-to-cap ratio at the end of the year will probably be a little less than 25% once the 9.25% is actually redeemed, so just kind of fall within that 30% ratio that our rating agencies like to see as a maximum. We still have around $500 million of capacity there. And we really have access to that just through our bank line. But even if we didn't have the bank line for some reason and access to the public markets, we know that we have free cash flow coming up in that $340 million, $360 million range next year. We would anticipate it for the year after that. And so that's just creates that added amount of liquidity for us. So think all those together, give us good confidence that, if we do have some downgrades, if we do have some impairments, that we'll be able to deal with that when the time comes.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Erik, I would add that, that's how we've handled this historically. We consider the buffer the liquidity we have, as Frank mentioned, the ability to add debt, but also the free cash flow. We know that free cash flow is there. We would rather wait until we
componenttext: Erik, I would add that, that's how we've handled this historically. We consider the buffer the liquidity we have, as Frank mentioned, the ability to add debt, but also the free cash flow. We know that free cash flow is there. We would rather wait until we know what the need is, if there's a need, before we put capital into companies. Because as you know, once was money is down in the companies, let's say we put too much in, it's difficult to get that money back out because you have to go through the process of getting an extraordinary dividend approved by the regulators. We feel very comfortable that we have more liquidity than we'll have any kind of a need for, but we don't see the point of putting it down to the companies until we actually need to.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: My first question was just on the agent force at -- in American Income. Appreciate the further comments on the union impact. I guess, could you elaborate more on just why the decline in the number of agents in that business and some of the things that are
componenttext: My first question was just on the agent force at -- in American Income. Appreciate the further comments on the union impact. I guess, could you elaborate more on just why the decline in the number of agents in that business and some of the things that are going on?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: I think the challenge is just how we're going to increase the agent growth at American Income. And as I stated in my comments, we've seen several factors this year that affected agent growth a negative way. The first is the higher unemployment. Recruiting
componenttext: I think the challenge is just how we're going to increase the agent growth at American Income. And as I stated in my comments, we've seen several factors this year that affected agent growth a negative way. The first is the higher unemployment. Recruiting for the year at American Income is actually up 5%. Of course, you had terminations, have been a little higher than the growth [ percent accrues ]. So we've had a flat agent count to the year. And as we go forward, we're changing our compensation system, improved our agent count and productivity. The changes include that we're going to increase our new agent first year commission and new monthly bonuses for agents to encourage retention. We're increasing bonus for managers to train new agents. And lastly, we're changing our bonuses for middle managers and agency owners for recruiting and new agent retention. We think that will have a positive impact in 2019. Our guidance for 2019 is 1% to 7% growth in the agent count at American Income.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just in Direct Response, the increase in expected margins there, what is it about what you're seeing in the performance of the block that causes you to feel like the go-forward expectations are increased? Is it lower incidence that's sort
componenttext: Got it. And then just in Direct Response, the increase in expected margins there, what is it about what you're seeing in the performance of the block that causes you to feel like the go-forward expectations are increased? Is it lower incidence that's sort of driving the favorable mortality? And any additional color you can provide there would be great.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, Steve (sic), we're really seeing favorable experience really across most this year's as well as really no specific particular causes of death or product types or anything to that effect. So it's fairly broad. And we actually have seen some impr
componenttext: Yes. Well, Steve (sic), we're really seeing favorable experience really across most this year's as well as really no specific particular causes of death or product types or anything to that effect. So it's fairly broad. And we actually have seen some improvements overall in the claims with respect to kind of what I'm going to say is our -- has been our problem issue years, that's 2010 to 2014, that we've talked a lot about over the past few years. And so we've seen some of the claims really moderate in those more recent issue years. So that gives us a little bit more comfort that at least the claim level in general that we're kind of seeing. And obviously, we're -- again, we'll see some fluctuations, but we then should be able to maintain that. And looking forward, tune in to 2019, we will expect the first couple of quarters to be lower margin, a little higher claim just due to the normal seasonality and the kind of running that same pattern that we would see that we saw this year.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: And Alex, I would add that when we say we're seeing a lower claims, it's really lower volume of claims. The average claim dollars stays pretty much the same.
componenttext: And Alex, I would add that when we say we're seeing a lower claims, it's really lower volume of claims. The average claim dollars stays pretty much the same.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Say, the Medicare Supplement sales, 40% of the increase, 14% comes from the group and 46% comes from the individual Medicare Supplement. I think we've seen strong growth in individual sales for the last year because market conditions are favorable from a
componenttext: Say, the Medicare Supplement sales, 40% of the increase, 14% comes from the group and 46% comes from the individual Medicare Supplement. I think we've seen strong growth in individual sales for the last year because market conditions are favorable from a pricing standpoint. Additionally, we've had good recruiting results over the past several quarters. The group is really harder to forecast. The group sales tend to be uneven, and they're impacted by the size of the groups. But we think we'll have some growth in group sales in 2019. We just -- it's so hard to predict at this point in time. In the Family Heritage, really, the increase has been driven by both productivity, an increase in the number of agents. And by productivity, it's the percentage of agents submitting. And the average premium written per agent has increased, and that's what's driving the sales in Family Heritage.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: I think that's fair. The general growth -- so we're kind of anticipating our statutory earnings, while it is a little bit early yet here for 2018. But we expect them to be up probably $15 million to $20 million over where we were in 2017. For the most par
componenttext: I think that's fair. The general growth -- so we're kind of anticipating our statutory earnings, while it is a little bit early yet here for 2018. But we expect them to be up probably $15 million to $20 million over where we were in 2017. For the most part, that's about a 4% growth, so growing pretty much in line with our overall growth in premiums. But clearly, the moderation of our obligations, where we've been having challenges in the past several years with the growing cost at Direct Response, some of the moderating of those claims, it's clearly been helpful. The higher interest rate, well, that's not going to help us much until 2019. And that will be, at least, a positive. And then when we'll receive some incremental benefit from the lower tax rate in 2018 as well.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: So from here, stat earnings should be able to grow in line with GAAP earnings?
componenttext: So from here, stat earnings should be able to grow in line with GAAP earnings?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we would expect that. Now if we do end up having some high-growth years, then that will tend to work against that statutory earnings. But if sales are growing in those lower single-digit numbers, at mid-single-digit numbers, then you're not g
componenttext: Yes. I think we would expect that. Now if we do end up having some high-growth years, then that will tend to work against that statutory earnings. But if sales are growing in those lower single-digit numbers, at mid-single-digit numbers, then you're not going to see quite as much stress on the -- on statutory earnings.

componenttext: I'm not sure exactly how to follow-up that last comment. The first question I have is just thinking about the midpoint of the 2019 guide. I think it was about $6.60. So at that midpoint, how should we be thinking about the overall portfolio yield and impact on excess investment income? And then I assume the upper and lower end of that range gives some flexibility for new money yields or portfolio yield to shift a bit.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, I think as far as the portfolio yield, we've been having declines in the yield, year-over-year declines in the range of 9 to 10 basis points. We've gotten to the point now where we're investing in what's coming off the portfolio that -- whereas
componenttext: Yes, John, I think as far as the portfolio yield, we've been having declines in the yield, year-over-year declines in the range of 9 to 10 basis points. We've gotten to the point now where we're investing in what's coming off the portfolio that -- whereas we were 5.56% for this year, we think that at the end of next year, the portfolio yield will be 5.53%. So we're only losing 3 basis points. So we're getting to that point where we're -- the portfolio yield and the investment rate are getting very close.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. That's about what we've got in terms of basis decline. The -- sorry.
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. That's about what we've got in terms of basis decline. The -- sorry.

componenttext: Yes. I would just say, John, you just thinking about some of the sensitivities, that from the plus or minus 25 basis points on those new -- on that new money yield over the course of the years, that ends up having about a $0.02 impact overall when you think about the highs and the lows and what impact that might have.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Got you, okay. And then the second question, I know it's early days yet and this stuff is going to be ferreted out over the course of a rather lengthy period of time. But Gary or Frank, any early thoughts on, conceptually or otherwise, how you think the n
componenttext: Got you, okay. And then the second question, I know it's early days yet and this stuff is going to be ferreted out over the course of a rather lengthy period of time. But Gary or Frank, any early thoughts on, conceptually or otherwise, how you think the new FASB long-duration accounting standards are going to impact your financial statements?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. It is pretty early. As you know, they did provide the final amendments here this quarter, and it'll be effective by 2021. And really at this point in time, we're still reviewing the amendments in determining what changes we'll ultimately need to make
componenttext: Yes. It is pretty early. As you know, they did provide the final amendments here this quarter, and it'll be effective by 2021. And really at this point in time, we're still reviewing the amendments in determining what changes we'll ultimately need to make to our systems and processes to be able to comply. So it would be a lot of work between now and then. I think at a very high level, you have a couple of things that are changing and add the -- total changes in assumptions with respect to your future cash flows, changes to those assumptions will have to flow through net income. And at least you have the potential for some of that to get unlocked. And then the kind of the -- really, the bigger change is going to be that you'll revalue reserves quarterly using internal market rate. But at least -- but those adjustments to the interest rate will flow through OCI, so won't impact overall current operations. So I think, in general, looks like that the companies that may be right, policies that have some of these margin risk benefits that are talked about in the guidance may tend to have a little bit more volatility because it's just a little bit harder to nail down those -- the future assumptions on those future cash flows. With the nature of our products, again, there's a lot of work, and we really haven't been able to see exactly what impact it's going to have on us. But we're hopeful that it may not be as volatile as we maybe once thought through the actual earnings, given the way that the guidances come out.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay, we'll stay tuned. I'm sure a lot more to go on that topic. And I've just got one more for you guys. Does your -- listen, I appreciate the lower asset leverage of your operation. I appreciate the noncallable liabilities, the, I mean, a complete lack
componenttext: Okay, we'll stay tuned. I'm sure a lot more to go on that topic. And I've just got one more for you guys. Does your -- listen, I appreciate the lower asset leverage of your operation. I appreciate the noncallable liabilities, the, I mean, a complete lack of a run-on-the-bank type of scenario, or risk. But you do have a very heavy exposure within your investment-grade portfolio to BBB securities. Just sort of circling back on, I think it was Erik's question earlier. As we're getting very late in the cycle here, is there any expectation of some sort of -- at the margin even, portfolio reallocation to move credit quality maybe a little bit higher and protect capital ratios against a professional downturn?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, John, I think we -- although we haven't changed our overall investment philosophy, we have made a few tweaks on what we're doing. One is we've invested more in municipal bonds than we have in the past. It gives us a little bit higher-quality bonds.
componenttext: Well, John, I think we -- although we haven't changed our overall investment philosophy, we have made a few tweaks on what we're doing. One is we've invested more in municipal bonds than we have in the past. It gives us a little bit higher-quality bonds. Also, there are certain issuers that we may have invested in, in the past and we aren't now because they have higher leverage or higher leverage than we prefer at this point into the cycle. So there -- we made some changes like that. But overall, the strategy is still the same.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Ryan Krueger with KBW.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: I had a follow-up to Bob's question on -- I guess, on longer-term earnings generation. You saw a little bit of uplift from tax reform, but fairly minor statutory rates, just given some of the cash tax changes. So I'm just wondering if you look longer term
componenttext: I had a follow-up to Bob's question on -- I guess, on longer-term earnings generation. You saw a little bit of uplift from tax reform, but fairly minor statutory rates, just given some of the cash tax changes. So I'm just wondering if you look longer term, will you see more of the tax benefits from tax reform start to emerge on a statutory basis, I guess, over a much longer period of time?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. We think the -- you're right. In the near term and kind of intermediate term, we believe there will be incremental benefits from the tax reform. We've kind of estimated initially, probably thinking in that $10 million to $15 million a year range. Onc
componenttext: Yes. We think the -- you're right. In the near term and kind of intermediate term, we believe there will be incremental benefits from the tax reform. We've kind of estimated initially, probably thinking in that $10 million to $15 million a year range. Once we get past year 8, because there are certain transition rules as part of that tax reform that's caused us to, if you will, pay back a portion of our tax reserves over the first 8 years. After that period of time, then we'll start to see much more significant benefit as a result of the tax reform. That's probably -- the transition rules are probably costing us -- will cost us somewhere in that $19 million, $20 million range a year. So that, that would free up after the year 8.

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. So once you get just past that year 8, you could see about a $20 million or so kind of uptick immediately?
componenttext: Okay, got it. So once you get just past that year 8, you could see about a $20 million or so kind of uptick immediately?

headline: Torchmark Corporation, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2018
componenttextpreview: That's right. And then, of course, statutory income growth and your overall taxable income base grows, that differential of being able to pay it at a 14% lower tax rate works in there as well. So you're going to be having that lift just on that growth of
componenttext: That's right. And then, of course, statutory income growth and your overall taxable income base grows, that differential of being able to pay it at a 14% lower tax rate works in there as well. So you're going to be having that lift just on that growth of that earnings, too.
